title: Filling out a Collection
content:
I've been reading the posts and archives and have found much of what I need. But I wonder if some of you could help me. I have been working with a partner doing architectural photography and this has expanded into a limited design company.   
   
I felt strongly that I needed to expand my type collection. I have the fonts that come with Photoshop CS and other versions and the Adobe Type Classic Collection and have been following your advice to shop around and buy fonts you like and I have bought a lot!   
   
But I wonder if there are some basic, useful fonts you would find indispensible in your collections and also the fonts you like the most.   
   
I know I will have to buy some fonts specifically to meet a customer's needs. I will spend another $500-$1,000 (preferably the 500) at this time on my general type collection and want to make sure that what i have is representative of a quality selecion.   
   
I'm using Windows.   
   
Thanks for reading this and for any help you can give me.   
   
Sharon
author: pearlstreet

comments.content:
I can't resist an advert for our collection :   
   
 [http://www.unionfonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.unionfonts.com/)   
   
You could get around 25 font families for that kind of money.   
   
Jim

Linotype has several extensive, highly affordable packages available.   
   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1788-6/compilationvaluepackages.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1788-6/compilationvaluepackages.html)   
   
I would recommend buying one of the following four packages (and then using the rest of your money to buy from some independent foundries, like Jim's, or maybe [www.typofonderie.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.typofonderie.com/), or [www.fontbureau.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.fontbureau.com/), [www.fountain.nu](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.fountain.nu/), or [www.buymyfonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.buymyfonts.com/)):   
   
Linotype Essentials 1 cost 400 Euro (you can pay in dollars, of course� costs in little bit more because the dollar has deflated recently), and includes a great selection of established classic typefamilies from the Linotype Library. Includes Helvetica Neue and Bauer Bodoni.   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1790-6/linotypeessentials1.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1790-6/linotypeessentials1.html)   
   
Linotype Essentials 2 is 465 Euro, and has slightly more less common families, like Sabon and Zapfino.   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1791-6/linotypeessentials2.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1791-6/linotypeessentials2.html)   
   
Fresh Cream has Akira Kobayashi's Conrad, which is the best new typeface ever (imho), along with some other durable families. Gerard Unger's Praxis and Demos are here, too, which have recently been selected as the official typefaces of the German government. 365 Euro   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1912-6/linotypefreshcream.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1912-6/linotypefreshcream.html)   
   
Frutiger's Life has all of the typefaces designed by Adrian Frutiger that have as of yet been digitized. That includes Univers and Frutiger, of course� It is a steal at 240 Euro.   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1793-6/frutigerslife.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1793-6/frutigerslife.html)   
   
Last, and perhaps least, is the Gundrun & Hermann Zapf collection, which is like Frutiger's Life, but with the two Zapfs' life's work instead. Palatino and Optima, among others, are here. 400 Euro.   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-1794-6/gudrunhermannzapfcollection.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1794-6/gudrunhermannzapfcollection.html)   
   
In the interest of full disclosure, I'll say that I work for Linotype� but I'm just an intern. I've beought type from them, though, and can attest that everything that our new type director touches _really does_ turn to gold�!   
   
Dan

Hi Jim,   
   
I bought a font from you when your website had just come online. Your service was wonderful and I have several more of your fonts on my list.   
   
Dan,   
   
I wish I had asked this question earlier. I have some of these fonts, but these packages look good. I agree about Conrad.   
   
Our business is based in Nantucket and that name is used a lot in business names. I've tried to find some fonts that show the Nantucket name as well as indicate the history and heritage of the island. I'm considering MVB Chanson d�Amour, ALT and wonder what you think of it. I like Golden Book too.   
   
I also want some quirky, even funky fonts and have shopped Chank, Fontdiner and P22.   
   
Thanks for the good advice. If you or anyone else has some more help, I would appreciate it.   
   
Sharon

Oh, I like that Storm Collection.   
   
I have bought a lot at Myfonts but I just wondered how blindly I was wandering. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)  
   
I'm also looking at 3islandpress fonts. They have New England influenced type.   
   
This is hard but it's so much fun.   
   
I'm still open for help from all but I thank those of you who have responded. I will study all your suggestions.   
   
Thank you,   
   
Sharon

Your dollars might not go very far with these, but I would look at them to see if there is a really outstanding font that will beautifully suit your firm's purpose: [www.typography.net](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.typography.net/) , [www.gerardunger.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.gerardunger.com/) , [www.teff.nl](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.teff.nl/)

Sharon, if you want New England, you really should look more into Font Bureau ( [www.fontbureau.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.fontbureau.com/) Boston), or anything from Tobias Frere-Jones at Hoefler & Frere-Jones Typography ( [www.typography.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.typography.com/)). Bitstream is in New England, too... and MyFonts... at least they're _headquartered_ in Cambridge.   
   
After having lived in Providence for four years, I really get a kick out of the Providence Type Foundry ( [http://www.provtype.com/index2.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.provtype.com/index2.html)), too; or at least its font names.   
   
Unfortuantely, I can't say that Linotype has anything distinctly "New England." We do sell a lot of typefaces to New Englanders, though.   
   
Yves, I think that **all** of Linotype's products are reasonalbly priced now (no, I'm not saying this just because I work in the _marketing_ department). I mean, the gold edition will still set you back 10 grand, but it is ENORMOUS.   
   
Most of the font collections are very nicely priced. The Take Type Collections [http://www.linotype.com/6-1785-6/taketype.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1785-6/taketype.html)   
are really broad, with a lot of one-off display faces, but they all have a few good text families (including the first appearance of Conrad, on Take Type 3!). Our new special packs sell five or six fonts apiece, at an average of 6 EUR a font, I think. [http://www.linotype.com/6-1788-6/compilationvaluepackages.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.linotype.com/6-1788-6/compilationvaluepackages.html)   
   
Plus, we will soon be offering student discounts (if we haven't had them before)   
   
And in the name of good, fair competition, I should add that the best of Unger's fonts are available from us, too ;)

Thanks so much,   
   
I like a lot of the Font Bureau collections but I think I like the Myfonts Linotype collection better to start with. That and the Storm czech collection. I can add some more individual fonts.   
The Unger fonts were very nice.   
   
I appreciate the help you have all given me in sorting this out.   
   
Sharon

Sharon Brunson ,   
   
Take a look at Lanston. I am in a position to make a deal. Frankly motivated. [http://lanstontype.com/lanstonaddress.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/lanstontype.com/lanstonaddress.html)   
   
 [http://www.lanstontype.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051627/http:/www.lanstontype.com/)   
   
Gerald Giampa   
Lanston Type Company

Thank you Mr. Giampa. I will certainly study your site.   
   
Sharon
